title: U.S. Second-Quarter Growth Slowed, Corporate Profits Rose
text:
WASHINGTON—The U.S. economic expansion cooled as it reached its 10th anniversary, despite strong pickups in corporate profits and consumer spending in the second quarter, with longer-run forces weighing on the outlook ahead.

U.S. gross domestic product—the broadest measure of the nation’s output of goods and services—rose at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 2.0% in the second quarter, a solid pace but down from a 3.1% rate in the first quarter and 2.9% overall in 2018, the Commerce Department said Thursday.

U.S. corporate profits rebounded in the second quarter as companies cut investment. A broad measure of corporate earnings—after taxes, without inventory valuation and capital consumption adjustments—rose 4.8% from the prior quarter. That came after corporate profits, which are often volatile on a quarterly basis, dropped 1.5% in both the first quarter of this year and the fourth quarter of 2018.

Looking over a longer period, they were up a more muted 1.7% in the second quarter from the same period a year before.

American companies faced earnings pressure earlier in the year for a number of reasons, including rising labor costs, limited pricing power and a strong dollar that makes U.S. exports more expensive.

“Whatever the numbers show for any individual quarter, we have to expect a weaker trend in corporate earnings growth in the next year,” said Ian Shepherdson, chief economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics.

Analysts noted that the level of U.S. corporate profits has barely changed over the past five years.

“For every dollar they sell, [companies] are not getting a lot back,” said Joseph Carson, a former chief economist at Alliance Bernstein who is now an independent consultant. “Consumer spending is strong but remember it’s the companies that pay their salaries and offer them jobs.”

The concern among economists is that future weakness in profits at American companies could spell trouble for the labor market if boardrooms slow hiring or even lay off workers to cut costs.

Weakness in inventory investment and trade exerted bigger drags on growth in the April-through-June period than previously thought, causing the Commerce Department to lower slightly its estimate of total second-quarter GDP growth to a 2.0% annual rate from the 2.1% pace previously estimated.

A closely watched gauge of business investment declined in the second quarter for the first time since early 2016. Nonresidential fixed investment—which reflects spending on software, research and development, equipment and structures—fell at a 0.6% rate.

Still, consumers’ spending drives about two-thirds of U.S. economic output, and an improving labor market has helped them provide continued fuel for economic growth.

U.S. households boosted spending at a 4.7% annual rate in the second quarter, the strongest pace since late 2014, shrugging off the uncertainty over trade policy and tariffs that rattled financial markets. That was stronger than the previously estimated 4.3% pace.

Consumers have continued to spend briskly since the second quarter, according to other recent data.

While consumer sentiment declined in August, according to separate readings from the Conference Board and the University of Michigan, the indexes still remain at a historically high level.

Target Corp. and Walmart Inc. were among the beneficiaries of strong consumer spending in recent months. Both retailers recently raised full-year earnings guidance and reported higher second-quarter sales.

Still, Target Chief Executive Brian Cornell warned during an earnings call last week that “as long as the trade situation remains fluid, it will present an additional layer of uncertainty and complexity as we plan our business.”

Bloomfield Hills, Mich.-based adjustable bed manufacturer Reverie said it held off on a planned expansion of a location in Buffalo, N.Y. in the second quarter due to tariff uncertainty.

“Originally the domestic manufacturing was fairly competitive—with the steel price increases and the component tariffs it’s kind of blown that up a little,” said CEO Martin Rawls-Meehan. The company has shifted some production to Vietnam and Taiwan “simply because that’s the only way we can compete,” he said.

The company, which has about 150 employees, cut some manufacturing jobs in the second quarter, although it boosted head count in other areas such as sales and operations.

“We’re doing well and we’re growing,” the CEO said, adding that “overall we’ve actually added some jobs, but we’re not going to add nearly as many as we planned to on the manufacturing side.”

Federal Reserve officials are likely to lower short-term interest rates at their meeting Sept. 17-18 to cushion the U.S. economy against the risks from slowing global growth and rising trade uncertainty. They cut rates in July for the first time since 2008.

Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, speaking last week in Jackson Hole, Wyo., cautioned that the Fed’s tools weren’t well suited to counter rising business and investor anxieties over the intensifying trade war.

The manufacturing sector has continued to struggle in the third quarter so far, with U.S. factory output falling in July from a month earlier, the Fed reported.

Forecasting firm Macroeconomic Advisers on Thursday projected GDP would rise at a 2.2% pace in the third quarter, now in its ninth week. The Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta’s GDPNow model most recently predicted a 2.3% growth rate.
